title: Prostate Tumor Volume & Density
description: Calculates prostate volume using ellipsoid formula and PSA density to help distinguish between benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) and prostate cancer. This tool assists in biopsy decision-making, risk stratification, and treatment planning for patients with elevated PSA levels.

parameters.name: prostate_length
parameters.description: Maximum anteroposterior (AP) diameter of prostate in cm

parameters.name: prostate_width
parameters.description: Maximum transverse (left-right) diameter of prostate in cm

parameters.name: prostate_height
parameters.description: Maximum craniocaudal (superior-inferior) diameter of prostate in cm

parameters.name: psa_value
parameters.description: Serum prostate-specific antigen (PSA) level in ng/mL

result.name: prostate_calculations
result.description: Calculated prostate volume and PSA density with clinical interpretation

ranges.interpretation: Below normal size, may indicate underdevelopment or atrophy.
Normal prostate size for adult males.
Mild enlargement, may cause some urinary symptoms.
Moderate enlargement, likely causing urinary symptoms.
Severe enlargement, likely causing significant urinary obstruction.
Very low probability of clinically significant prostate cancer.
Moderate probability of prostate cancer, consider additional evaluation.
High probability of prostate cancer, biopsy strongly recommended.
Very high probability of clinically significant prostate cancer.

references: Terris MK, Stamey TA. Determination of prostate volume by transrectal ultrasound. J Urol. 1991;145(5):984-7. doi: 10.1016/s0022-5347(17)38491-9.

Benson MC, Whang IS, Olsson CA, McMahon DJ, Cooner WH. The use of prostate specific antigen density to enhance the predictive value of intermediate levels of serum prostate specific antigen. J Urol. 1992;147(3 Pt 2):817-21. doi: 10.1016/s0022-5347(17)37394-9.

Kalish J, Cooner WH, Graham SD Jr. Serum PSA adjusted for volume of transition zone (PSATZ) is more accurate than PSA adjusted for total gland volume (PSAD) in detecting adenocarcinoma of the prostate. Urology. 1994;43(5):601-6. doi: 10.1016/0090-4295(94)90170-8.

Zlotta AR, Egawa S, Pushkar D, Govorov A, Kimura T, Kido M, et al. Prevalence of prostate cancer on autopsy: cross-sectional study on unscreened Caucasian and Asian men. J Natl Cancer Inst. 2013;105(14):1050-8. doi: 10.1093/jnci/djt151.
formula: Prostate Volume (mL) = Length × Width × Height × π/6; PSA Density (ng/mL²) = PSA (ng/mL) ÷ Prostate Volume (mL)
notes: Prostate volume calculated using ellipsoid formula with π/6 correction factor
PSA density threshold of 0.15 ng/mL/cm³ commonly used to distinguish benign from malignant
Normal prostate volume is approximately 25-30 mL in adult males
PSA density >0.15 associated with higher probability of prostate cancer
Particularly useful in PSA 'gray zone' (4-10 ng/mL) for biopsy decision-making
Should be interpreted alongside clinical findings, DRE, and patient risk factors
Imaging measurements should be obtained from transrectal ultrasound (TRUS) or MRI
Age-related prostate enlargement should be considered in interpretation
May help guide active surveillance vs. treatment decisions
Useful for monitoring prostate size changes over time
Consider transition zone volume for more precise cancer risk assessment
Accuracy depends on precise imaging measurements and proper technique
